summary: This is a defense expert disclosure filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team in her criminal case. It outlines the expected testimony of two defense experts, Dr. Elizabeth Loftus and Dr. Park Dietz, who will challenge the reliability of witness memories and the concept of 'grooming' as applied to Maxwell. This document is a defense filing in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, likely a notice of expert witnesses. It outlines psychological pathways to false allegations of sexual assault and introduces several defense experts who will testify on topics including forensic psychiatry, prosecutorial misconduct, computer forensics, financial investigation, and document analysis.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330 (AIN)), for whom this expert disclosure is being submitted by her counsel.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon Morgan and Foreman, P.C. who is submitting this expert disclosure on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Elizabeth Loftus
persons.context: A psychologist and memory expert who will testify about the fallibility of memory, the creation of false memories, and the effects of suggestion.

persons.name: Park Dietz
persons.context: A forensic psychiatrist who will testify to challenge the prosecution's grooming theory, hindsight bias, and the pathways to false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Dr. Rocchio
persons.context: A prosecution expert whose opinions on grooming and victim vulnerabilities are being challenged by the defense expert, Dr. Park Dietz.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as a brilliant but flawed man with Cluster B personality traits who used his wealth and power to manipulate people. The case involves allegations Maxwell recruited minors for him.

persons.name: Steve Bannon
persons.context: Mentioned in reference to a videotaped interview where Jeffrey Epstein discussed different kinds of power.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Cited by Epstein in an interview as an example of a person with political power.

persons.name: Gerry Edelman
persons.context: Cited by Epstein in an interview as an example of a person with intellectual power.

persons.name: Natalie Bennett
persons.context: Co-author of a cited academic paper questioning the construct of grooming in child sexual abuse.

persons.name: William O'Donohue
persons.context: Co-author of multiple cited academic papers on grooming and false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Jessica Engle
persons.context: Co-author of a cited paper on pathways to false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Emily R. Dworkin
persons.context: Cited as author of meta-analysis on mental disorder risks associated with sexual assault.

persons.name: Caron Zlotnick
persons.context: Cited as author on research about chronicity in PTSD.

persons.name: Meredith Warshaw
persons.context: Co-author with Caron Zlotnick on PTSD research.

persons.name: Ryan Hall
persons.context: Defense expert in forensic psychiatry who will offer opinions and diagnoses.

persons.name: Bennett Gershman
persons.context: Distinguished Professor of Law at Pace University, expected to testify on prosecutorial best practices and integrity.

persons.name: Robert Kelso
persons.context: CEO of Forensic Pursuit, expected to testify about user data, metadata, and computer forensics related to seized devices.

persons.name: Gerald LaPorte
persons.context: Forensic chemist expected to analyze documents for dates of creation, completeness, alteration, and manipulation.

persons.name: Jennifer Naso
persons.context: Document examiner trained by the U.S. Secret Service, expected to analyze documents for authenticity and authorship.

connections.description: The document states Maxwell is accused of recruiting and grooming minors to provide sexualized massages for Epstein, which the defense labels 'grooming-by-proxy'.
Pagliuca is submitting this legal expert disclosure on behalf of his client, Ghislaine Maxwell.
Dr. Loftus is a defense expert witness retained to testify on memory issues relevant to Maxwell's case.
Dr. Dietz is a defense expert witness retained to testify on forensic psychiatry issues to challenge the prosecution's theory against Maxwell.
Epstein gave a videotaped interview to Steve Bannon where he discussed power.
Epstein cited Clinton as an example of political power in an interview.
Dr. Dietz's testimony is designed to directly counter and critique the opinions of the prosecution's expert, Dr. Rocchio.
Hall is a defense expert providing forensic psychiatry opinions for Maxwell's case.
Gershman is a defense expert expected to testify on prosecutorial integrity for Maxwell's case.
Kelso is a defense computer forensics expert analyzing evidence for Maxwell's case.

events.title: Defense Expert Disclosure Filing
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files a formal disclosure of their expert witnesses and the scope of their expected testimony.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea Referenced
events.description: The document references that Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to having sexual contact with post-pubescent minors, which is cited as an example of outcome knowledge that can create hindsight bias.

events.title: Defense Expert Witness Notice Filed
events.description: Defense files notice outlining psychological theories of false allegations and listing multiple expert witnesses for Ghislaine Maxwell's trial.

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Haddon Morgan and Foreman, P.C., 150 East 10th Avenue, Denver, Colorado 80203
University of California, Irvine School of Law
University of Virginia School of Law
keyFacts: The defense plans to call memory expert Dr. Elizabeth Loftus to testify about the fallibility of memory and how false memories can be created through suggestion, media coverage, and conversations.

The defense plans to call forensic psychiatrist Dr. Park Dietz to challenge the prosecution's theory of 'grooming,' arguing it imputes motive without evidence and that a theory of 'grooming-by-proxy' has no scientific basis.

Dr. Dietz will testify about cognitive biases like 'hindsight bias' (judging past events as more predictable after knowing the outcome) and the 'halo effect' (where positive traits influence unrelated judgments), suggesting they may have affected the investigation and allegations against Maxwell.

The document cites Jeffrey Epstein's own description of being drawn to people with different kinds of power (political, physical, intellectual) and his manipulative use of 'Cluster B personality traits'.

The defense outlines multiple 'pathways to false allegations of sexual assault,' including lying, false memories, implied consent, and personality disorders, to argue that not all allegations are true.

The defense outlines multiple psychological pathways that could lead to false allegations of sexual assault, including false memory, intoxication, and personality disorders like antisocial, borderline, and histrionic.

Several defense expert witnesses are introduced, including a forensic psychiatrist (Ryan Hall), a prosecutorial misconduct scholar (Bennett Gershman), a computer forensics specialist (Robert Kelso), a forensic chemist (Gerald LaPorte), and a document examiner (Jennifer Naso).
The filing cites academic research, including work by Elizabeth Loftus on false memories and meta-analyses on mental health outcomes after sexual assault, to support its arguments.
The defense reserves the right to rebut testimony about 'grooming' and other opinions after the government's case-in-chief.
